history.content:
The labs could take a while if you mess up on something, but imo they were pretty fun for me. I thought it was pretty cool how we were like readily using the stuff we were learning in lecture for parts of the lab project; ie recently after learning PCA, we figure out how to get our car to classify spoken words into different commands. Controls wise, getting our car to drive relatively straight was pretty neat, but there wasn't anything too profound about modifying a value until a thing worked better. There is a decent amount of breadboarding for 16B lab,  but there's also a fair bit on coding. You can play to the strengths of your group (I did most of the circuits sided things and my partners handled more of the coding).

______

16b labs are a lot more intense/more work than 16a labs in my opinion. You have more complicated breadboarding tasks (they give you a bigger one), and labs take longer as well. If you like circuits and building things, you'll have the time of your life though :). 

______

The third perspective here; EE16b labs are considerably longer than EE16a labs but you'll enjoy them if you are interested in controls/robotics (making a car that drives depending on voice inputs as a final project is way more fun than the majority of EE16a labs imo)

You can play to the strengths of your group (I did most of the circuits sided things and my partners handled more of the coding).

______

I thought it was pretty cool how we were like readily using the stuff we were learning in lecture for parts of the lab project; ie recently after learning PCA, we figure out how to get our car to classify spoken words into different commands. Controls wise, getting our car to drive relatively straight was pretty neat, but there wasn't anything too profound about modifying a value until a thing worked better. There is a decent amount of breadboarding for 16B lab,  but there's also a fair bit on coding. You can play to the strengths of your group (I did most of the circuits sided things and my partners handled more of the coding).

The labs could take a while if you mess up on something, but imo they were pretty fun for me. I thought it was pretty cool how we were like readily using the stuff we were learning in lecture for parts of the lab project; ie recently after learning PCA, we figure out how to get our car to classify spoken words into different commands.

I enjoy EE 16A but don't really like the labs (using breadboards for building circuits, soldering, etc.). How are the labs in 16B like (especially control)? I'd like to learn some control theory and hope to get some inputs.
history.subject: How is labs in EE 16B like?
